2013-09-24-bullet-journal-workflow.summary:
In this post, I share my discovery and experience with the Bullet Journal - an analog to-do list system. Task lists often get lost amongst the waves of daily happenings whether they're physically on paper or digital. After trying out several productivity hacks, I found that the Bullet Journal has been the key to my productivity increase.

The method is surprisingly straightforward. Developed by Ryder Carrol, it involves splitting the to-do list into three categories - tasks, events and notes - each marked with a different symbol. The real beauty of the system lies in its rollover approach, keeping the list relevant as it moves with you from day-to-day and month-to-month. Each day starts with a fresh list where unchecked tasks from the previous day are either deemed irrelevant or moved to the new list, avoiding old task build-up.

Starting each month, I jot down long-term goals and update them daily. The notebook is indexed in the beginning and pages being numbered as they go supports easy track of these goals. Despite the structure of daily and monthly lists, the system also leaves space for flexibility. More than simply easy to maintain, the Bullet Journal has contributed significantly to my increased productivity by instilling structure in my daily routine and reducing task overlook. Thus, it has proven to be more than just a short-term fix for staying organized.

2014-02-07-fullpage-screenshots-in-firef.summary:
If you've also found yourself trying to capture full page screenshots for your portfolio or any other purpose, you may have experienced the frustration of struggling with reloads, bugs, or unrendered fonts when using browser extensions. You might not believe it, but Firefox actually has a native way of taking full page screenshots that requires just one line of code. You will no longer have to deal with painstakingly stitching together multiple screenshots of a webpage.

Let me tell you how it works! Simply navigate to the page you wish to capture, and open up Firefox's Developer Tools command line using `shift f2`. You can also press `fn`, if your keyboard rebinding changes `f2`'s usage. Then, type in `screenshot --fullpage YourFileNameHere` and that's it! You'll have your screenshot, showing not just the visible content but the whole webpage down to its last pixel. If you are in a hurry, you can opt not to include a filename; Firefox will name the image using the current date and time. A small note, you may notice a slight streak of transparency on the right hand side of the screenshot when you view it in Photoshop. But considering the convenience, it's a trivial drawback. Try it out for yourself and you can see the full page screenshots I took using this method over on my portfolio page.

2015-08-05-internet-fridge.summary:
While the concept of an internet-connected fridge has been brought up time and again, most of us are yet to have one in our kitchens. But why is that? What are the challenges in bringing this IoT dream into reality and what benefits would it have if it did exist? 

As I discuss in great detail, adding internet to a fridge or any other device isn't particularly beneficial by itself. The true potential of IoT lies in enabling us to access our devices through the internet, rather than simply accessing the internet through our devices. Using sensors, we can monitor when components are about to fail, send a webcam snapshot of the fridge interior to our phone, or even track the state of the food stored within. 

Envisioning this kind of smart fridge is easy, but making it a reality is far more challenging. The long development cycles, infrequent purchase habits, and the fact that white-goods manufacturers are not software companies paints a bleak picture. Creating the necessary user-friendly software is tough while making user-friendly hardware isn’t a walk in the park either – combining the two is a mammoth task. These difficulties, coupled with market resistance to pricier products and the unattractiveness of the business model to the current incumbents, contribute to the slow progression of the Internet Fridge.

So, are start-ups the answer? They are known for their embrace of innovation and quick iteration cycles, characteristics much needed for this cause. But the complexities and cost-inefficiencies of hardware development can delay growth. What we need is a large, established company that values innovation and design, with a strong foundation in both hardware and software sectors, and the financial capacity for long-term investments.

Given these challenges, it is unlikely we'll witness the advent of the ideal Internet Fridge soon. Although it is an intriguing proposition, and one that could indeed make our lives more convenient, the journey there is a complex and difficult one yet to be embarked upon.

2016-01-20-web-apps.summary:
The native app or web app debate is a contentious one, with staunch supporters on both sides. In my opinion, web apps - websites that mimic the behaviors of apps - are a crucial tool a startup can benefit from. To many, the definition of web apps and websites can appear blurred, but I believe their differentiation mostly lies in their usage.

The popularity of native apps, especially on iPads and iPhones, is often attributed to the poor iOS browsing experience. Native apps also have an advantage as they can access device features more conveniently than a website. However, for startups building their first product, the web is the clear winner when used on an actual computer. 

During the early stages of a new venture, resources are scarce and teams generally excel in only a few key competences. Hence in these cases, a shared focus is necessary to avoid waste of resources. Building a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) for every available platform would split resources and slow down the process - which can be debilitating when you are trying to develop a product-market fit.

Luckily, this is where web apps shine. The web is versatile and universal, bypassing device compatibility issues that native apps struggle with. From an update perspective, deploying a new update or bugfix is much simpler with web apps. There is no need for outside approval or user download. 

Looking ahead, a successful app would want to branch out to multiple platforms. Having a decent Application Programming Interface (API) allows you to plug any front-end into the bulk your app's functionality, saving you the trouble of rebuilding the entire app from scratch. This could be especially simplified if your endpoint prototype is initially web-based. In terms of workforce, hiring developers with experience in web apps is easier due to their prevalence. 

In conclusion, if you are moving towards building an MVP, I'd recommend focusing on creating a web app. It's a time-saving, flexible option that sets you on your path towards success.

Even simple things, like clear directions for input or well-placed placeholder text, can make a significant difference. Therefore, while developers understandably seek ease, they must prioritise user experience and avoid treating aligned coding practices as universal solutions.

2017-01-05-calculating-reading-speed.summary:
In my pursuit of understanding whether displaying an approximate reading time would affect reader engagement, I've conducted a small experiment. My initial hypothesis was that a reading-time indication would increase click-throughs by providing users useful data. 

I found various examples of reading-time-calculation functions. My approach diverged in that I prioritized complete understanding, clarity and separation of concerns, hence, separating calculation logic from display logic. I implemented this concept in the WordPress context, where content-manipulation is for plugins and display is for themes.

For calculation of reading time, a JavaScript function was used. The process involved counting words and dividing by the reading speed. Displaying time included converting seconds to a minutes-and-seconds format. Here, modular arithmetic helped me find the remaining seconds in a minute. 

I wanted to show a more ‘human’ result so I used a dynamic approach to create messages based on how closely the total length was to a rounded minute. Hence, if I ended up with approximately 2 seconds remaining, it would indicate ‘nearly a minute’. Lastly, I made use of Karl Rixon's solution to convert raw integers to strings. 

The final step was to combine everything for my WordPress post content. I’m yet to see the outcome and whether or not this will achieve higher click-through rates is to be determined. Nonetheless, it was a fascinating dive into the problem.

2017-02-15-svg-markup.summary:
SVGs or Scalable Vector Graphics, complex as they are, hold immense power and potential. They can produce sharper and clearer results as compared to rasterized images like PNGs without requiring different files for each size. Using a single SVG file for all image sizes not only reduces HTTP requests but also the total page weight.

The language of SVGs, derived from XML, is relatively simple to master once you know what tags to look out for. The structure of SVG markup starts with an opening tag (`<svg>`) and ends with a closing tag (`</svg>`), similar to HTML. The main concept is using tags like `<path/>`, `<circle/>`, and `<rect/>` to build shapes within the SVG.

The SVGs can also be styled using CSS, offering a fine-grained control over individual parts of an icon. This control extends to transitions, animations, and positioning as well, providing an opportunity for developers to get more creative with their designs. Using CSS animations, a simple loading graphic can be transformed into an appealing and interactive design element. Can you imagine such an advantage with just playing around SVGs and CSS? Don't worry, the only limit appears to be the creativity and imagination of the developers who build them.

2020-12-30-web-audio-delay.summary:
In this blog post, we walk through replicating a delay pedal using JavaScript's Web Audio API. After initiatiing an audio context to connect with the browser's audio capabilities, we go into creating an analogue _signal path_ using an oscillator and a gain node. Throughout the process, we ensure the functionality works on multiple browser types.

Our sound’s initial stop and start functions feel jarring, so we utilise a gain node to soften this. We later create random pitches for our sound to enhance its musical feeling. These pitches use an array of note values, creating a melody within the C major scale.

Duplication of notes gives our sound a more 'full' feeling. However, instead of duplicating it entirely, we transpose the second sound to be seven steps higher - creating a more harmonious combination. Then, we introduce an effects unit in our signal path right between the instrument and the mixer. This unit takes the signal, modifies it, and sends it back to the mixer alongside the original signal. 

Though it works, this merely creates a single delay. We thereafter introduce the idea of feedback, a principle of feeding back a fraction of the delayed signal back into the delay module. This achieves an audible delay creating fuller, more dynamic effects. Finally, we enable interaction through HTML range elements, allowing tweaking of delay duration and feedback level for diverse sounds.

This post showcases the broad capabilities of the browser's audio context, opening the door to endless creativity. Feel free to use this information for your own sound experiments and don't hesitate to share your creations!

It should also be easy to remember, allowing it to govern my choices throughout the year.

In 2019, my theme was "shipping"; focusing on completing and releasing my projects. It was a challenging goal since I was used to tinkering without necessarily finishing. The result was a successful increase in product launches and a shift in approach that requires further work. In 2020, my theme was "action", symbolizing personal responsibility. The year certainly tested my resolve, but the theme was unmistakably apt. 

As for 2021, I chose a dual theme that reflects my reignited passion for music and my commitment to blogging. Calling it my "Year of Writing", my aim is to release my music and double down on blogging. Given that both passions involve 'writing' in different forms, I find this theme fittingly comprehensive and I'm eager to see what it brings. Following a "learning in public” approach, I've been sharing my learning process on my Instagram feed while uploading completed works on my YouTube channel. 2021-09-27-podcasting-equipment.summary:
In the planning of a new podcast, I have compiled and shared some "Podcast Equipment 101" tips for newbies in the game. To record a decent podcast, you need a good microphone, a connection between your mic and the computer, and recording software. 

The quality difference between a cheap dedicated microphone and basic methods such as earbuds is significant. Good podcasting mics include dynamic mics, condenser mics, and lavalier mics. Connections come into play when connecting your mic to the computer to record. This typically involves an XLR cable running from the mic to an audio interface that connects to the computer via USB. Some podcast-focused mics can directly connect to the computer via USB, negating the need for an audio interface.

When it comes to software, many options exist depending upon your role in the podcast. If editing, a full Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) is necessary, but if you are only a host or guest, all you need is simple software capturing your microphone's audio. 

In sum, if you are not editing, a decent USB microphone is enough, but if you want top-notch quality, an SM7B mic with requisite addons like a Cloudlifter preamp, an XLR cable, and the Scarlett Solo audio interface is the best bet. And, if you are the editor, Logic Pro is the recommended DAW to invest in. Remember that your recording technique is as important as your equipment. Always use headphones, keep the mic close to mouth, reduce noise, minimize flat reflective surfaces while recording, and control the surface directly behind the mic.

2022-02-25-wordle-node-script.summary:
In my latest blog post, I take you on my journey to explore how command-line scripts can leverage the power of data in finding an optimal sequence of starting words while playing Wordle. While I acknowledge that the craze for this word game is almost over, I want to share how even simple scripts that are executed in your terminal can help you navigate large amounts of data efficiently, something we humans aren't particularly good at. As I didn't want to "solve" Wordle but merely optimize my initial guesses, I created a code to find a sequence of guesses that covers most common consonants.

The first major finding from running my script was that the most common letters in the entire Wordle dictionary were the vowels, and 'S' was the most common letter. However, since vowels are more commonly used later in the game, I focused on discovering the most common consonants.

The search for the best sequence of words revealed that not all combinations of the most common letters form valid words. Getting rid of the extra letters around the core group opened up several options. After a few trials, I found that ‘trend’ seemed the most satisfactory first word. Again, including the previous word in the ‘exc’ argument and adding new target letters to the ‘inc’ argument, I ran the script again. 

After all this fun experimentation, I learned that writing scripts need not be as daunting as it appears. In fact, it can assist you with repetitive tasks and even save you a lot of time. Yes, you might spend a few days writing a script to automate a task that could be done manually in a few hours, but who wouldn't prefer an excuse to delve into some coding fun?

2023-09-30-improving-svg-chart-interacti.summary:
The blog post is about improving the interactivity of SVG charts, especially scatter plots, using voronoi diagrams. The writer shares his experience with hover-triggered tooltips, especially their usability problem owing to the precision required to target points. To overcome this, the writer proposes increasing the size of the points but notes that this solution interferes with the design of the plot.

The author then shares his solution of adding a 'hitbox' or buffer area around each point. This allows for larger targets without sacrificing the visual quality of the plot. He demonstrates how this can be achieved on a scatter plot using SVG's 'group' tag to replace a single data point with two circles. However, he also notes a potential problem - overlapping hitboxes, which can cause issues when there are a lot of points on the graph.

The writer then introduces the main part of the blog - using Voronoi diagrams, which split the chart area into cells assigned to each data point, creating a large hitbox without overlaps. He explains the concepts and demonstrates how to employ a Voronoi diagram using D3.js, a JavaScript library for creating data visualizations in SVG. He outlines the steps involved, from creating a Delaunay triangulation object to converting this into a Voronoi diagram.

The writer finishes with some practical tips for applying this technique, including using event listeners to enhance the interactivity of the chart by highlighting active points or displaying tooltips. He asserts that this way can greatly enhance SVG chart interactivity and it requires only a few extra lines of code when using D3.js. He says if already familiar with attaching event listeners and toggling class names based on the state, readers should be able to get up to speed easily with Voronoi diagrams.
